December the 9th will be
the date of the public initiation of Tau Beta Pi, honorary Engineering fraternity,
it was announced today by
President Farinholt. The
corresponding function of
Omicron Delta Kappa will
be held on December the
16th, President Jarrett announced.
Each of these organizations takes men in twice a
year, in the fall and in the
spring. Each is regarded as
•the highest honor of its kind
in the university and the public initiations are well attended.

Eight Johns Hopkins cross
country men will travel to Annapolis tomorrow morning to meet
the Naval Academy in a three and
a half mile run. The eight men
are: Gwinn, Scheibel, Day, Kirkpatrick, Kelly, V. Scheidt. Two
more will be picked from those
who make the best showing this
week.
Navy has two good men in cross
country: Bailey and O'Connor.
Bailey was the best miler the
Academy had last year; while
O'Conner, a youngster, beat the
Navy, record for the two-mile run
last year when he was a plebe.
Besides these two men, Navy's
aggregation of runners is not as
well balanced a team as Maryland,
who raced to victory over the Jay
runners by one point, last week, at
College Park.
Bailey and O'Connor should
give Dick Gwinn, who won .last
week in one second over the
course's record time, a hard run.

A BUILDER OF MORALE
With the St. John's game only a little over a week from today, our vigilant reporters have not yet brought in tidings of any
move on the part of either the Pep Committee or the cheer leaders
to arrange for a bonfire. If a move toward a bonfire has already
been made, so much the better. If not, some action ought to be
taken at once.
Perhaps this urging of a bonfire seems trivial or even childish. Why should the NEWS-LETTER, you may say, seriously advocate the collection of a huge pile of boxes, and its subsequent
burning accompanied by a large volume of noise? That, however, is not the point, such a thing as a pre-game bonfire cannot
be judged at its face value.
That indefinable quality known as college spirit is at the root
of the matter. We cannot explain this spirit; it is one of those
expressions of fine and unselfish loyalty which has no logical explanation. All we know is that we believe in it just as have those
who have gone before us did.
At Hopkins, as at most colleges, this esprit de corps centers
largely around athletics. The team, playing its hardest with a
feeling that in some way it is working for the alma mater, and
the rest of the students, behind it to a man, create an enthusiasm
and solidarity which is very beneficial to the college.
The bonfire is the place to develop this enthusiasm and support. As we have said, it may appear absurd, but it is there
that spirit is rampant. Few who have circled around the blazing
pyramid or marched down Charles street behind a wheezing band
have failed to develop a more intense thrill of pride at the mention of the name of Hopkins.
True, the primary purpose of the rally is to work up enthusiasm to urge the team on to victory the following day. In the
past it has often been effectual; we trust it will continue to be.
But win or lose, the bonfire accomplishes a great deal in building
up college morale.

DR. EDMUNDS
Although news of his departure has been released for some
time, the fact that Dr. Edmunds has actually left the University
is difficult to realize. Dr. Edmunds' presence on the campus, and
in the efficiently organized Half Century office has been too deeply
impressed on the undergraduate memory to be easily forgotten.
The arrangement of the Half Century Celebration was a
tremendous task. The planning of the affair and the direction of
the great mass of detail were for the most part in the hands of
Dr. Edmunds. The success of the Anniversary was due in a
very large measure to his efforts.
We are sorry to see Dr. Edmunds leave Hopkins. It is true
that he is going into a larger field, one in which he is probably
more deeply interested; and it is equally certain that under the
direction of Dr. Ames the work will go on with as much success.
This, however, does not prevent our feeling that Hopkins has
lost a devoted worker and a distinct personality.

"YES and NO"
We all recognize, more or less, vividly the comparative
lethargy that follows examination; either by the faculty, an ardent
Goucherite or a fraternity. Now that rushing season is gone we
are minus a ready and efficacious self-excuser for our conscience,
that too well worn fallacy that after rushing season "to work
and sane living." In place of this talisman we substitute a term
that sounds well at home; "goes over" with some of the faculty
and has all the ear marks, but none of the drudgery, of absorbing knowledge. We call it "browsing" in the library. Perhaps,
in days gone it was possible in the Main Library to quite lose
oneself in a perusal of a favorite book, magazine or periodical
that catered to one's particular taste. And even now between
disturbed glances across the library at a glaring inch or so of
flesh between a jet dress and black-colored hose, we are conscious of an occasional interest in things pedagogical.
Our interest here is rather simple; so dubious in nature that
we hesitate to offer it. However, there is a little blue paper bound
pamphlet on the horseshoe table in the Main Library that is interesting from the point of view that novelty provokes interest.
As for example, if upon sitting down at a piano you were suddenly endowed with the power to produce sounds that were recognized as music, without previous knowledge, or acquisition of
skill. We picked up the little book to examine it, perfunctorily
as we do many foreign publications. Its title is "Academia pro
Interlingua." We leaved it over and were for the next few minutes engrossed in conveying to our mind concrete, definite images.
At first we were convinced that it was Latin—but voted that assumption out since we were reading it! Which is impossible.
On one of the pages we found the following which cleared the
fog considerably.
"Virtutes de Interlingua."
"Academia consilia pro Interlingua
Vocabulario internationale, Othographia latino, sine grammatica."
Orthographia latino redde interlingua intelligible sine studio
ad lectore que habe cognitione, et superficiale, de latino, id es ad
omne sacerdote, advocato, medico, professore, in toto mundus.
Suppressione de grammatica permitte ad lectore que ignora
latino, de lege et scribe in IL cum auxilio de solo vocabulario
latino."
We hesitate to say more of our reaction to the book, since
we have no desire to be identified with championing it. We wish
simply to wonder why the idea has not been exploited further.
Is it not novel that one may pick up a book produced by Polish
followers, published in Torino (wherever that is) and read it
without hesitation or study in America? What are the chief
objections to such a language; at least superficially, may we appeal to some member of the graduate department in Modern Languages to enlighten us. We are assured from many sources that
such a reply would be interesting reading.

MARSHALL NEILAN'S

*

To the Editor of YES AND No.
Dear Sir:
The Editor of YES AND NO was right in predicting that there
are supporters of a given policy, "however bad" it may be. We
do not believe, however, that the recent open week was altogether
bad; certainly it was not useless.
No matter how well a student knows a given fraternity before joining it, he is bound to find out later some things he was
not aware of. It is essential that the pledge know the character
and ideals of his would-be fraternity brothers, as well as their
social standing. We doubt if such a knowledge can be obtained
on the day of pledging.
The question of expense to the fraternity is mentioned by
the Editor; we are of the opinion that freshmen should pay their
own way at banquets and theatres. It is up to the fraternities
to so regulate their entertainments as not to impoverish themselves.
Lastly, we believe that ideals, no matter how hazy, are a
beneficial influence; they tend to place fraternity competition on
a higher, cleaner plane.
Sincerely,
RUSTICUS.

FRATERNITIES SET
INITIATION DATES
December the 9th will be
the date of the public initiation of Tau Beta Pi, honorary Engineering fraternity,
it was announced today by
President Farinholt. The
corresponding function of
Omicron Delta Kappa will
be held on December the
16th, President Jarrett announced.
Each of these organizations takes men in twice a
year, in the fall and in the
spring. Each is regarded as
•the highest honor of its kind
in the university and the public initiations are well attended.

TUDOR-STUART CLUB
ELECTS FOUR
Four men were elected to
the Tudor and Stuart Club
at a meeting of the Board of
Governors Wednesday afternoon. All of the men were
taken from the Junior Class
and are immediately admitted to full privileges of the
endowed organization.

The officers have definitely decided to close the seasson wtih the
Home Concert at the Maryland
Casualty Club House on Friday

preparatory to this, and a lengthening of the season might prove
to be an anti-climax.

Eight Johns Hopkins cross
country men will travel to Annapolis tomorrow morning to meet
the Naval Academy in a three and
a half mile run. The eight men
are: Gwinn, Scheibel, Day, Kirkpatrick, Kelly, V. Scheidt. Two
more will be picked from those
who make the best showing this
week.
Navy has two good men in cross
country: Bailey and O'Connor.
Bailey was the best miler the
Academy had last year; while
O'Conner, a youngster, beat the
Navy, record for the two-mile run
last year when he was a plebe.
Besides these two men, Navy's
aggregation of runners is not as
well balanced a team as Maryland,
who raced to victory over the Jay
runners by one point, last week, at
College Park.
Bailey and O'Connor should
give Dick Gwinn, who won .last
week in one second over the
course's record time, a hard run.

\\That little information that has
been secured shows that Randolph-Macon has won but one
game so far this season. They
showed a complete reversal of
form over their previous contests
when they defeated Bridgewater
Academy, 25-0, at Harrisonville
Saturday. Bridgewater is not said
to have a strong team by any
means and the team was played
in place of Virginia, which postponed its contest until a later date.

practically the same team that the
Black and Blue eleven defeated

caught by ends who seemed to
pop up under them, and often
great gains were made, though
this mode of aerial attack proved
rather inconsistent.

A BUILDER OF MORALE
With the St. John's game only a little over a week from today, our vigilant reporters have not yet brought in tidings of any
move on the part of either the Pep Committee or the cheer leaders
to arrange for a bonfire. If a move toward a bonfire has already
been made, so much the better. If not, some action ought to be
taken at once.
Perhaps this urging of a bonfire seems trivial or even childish. Why should the NEWS-LETTER, you may say, seriously advocate the collection of a huge pile of boxes, and its subsequent
burning accompanied by a large volume of noise? That, however, is not the point, such a thing as a pre-game bonfire cannot
be judged at its face value.
That indefinable quality known as college spirit is at the root
of the matter. We cannot explain this spirit; it is one of those
expressions of fine and unselfish loyalty which has no logical explanation. All we know is that we believe in it just as have those
who have gone before us did.
At Hopkins, as at most colleges, this esprit de corps centers
largely around athletics. The team, playing its hardest with a
feeling that in some way it is working for the alma mater, and
the rest of the students, behind it to a man, create an enthusiasm
and solidarity which is very beneficial to the college.
The bonfire is the place to develop this enthusiasm and support. As we have said, it may appear absurd, but it is there
that spirit is rampant. Few who have circled around the blazing
pyramid or marched down Charles street behind a wheezing band
have failed to develop a more intense thrill of pride at the mention of the name of Hopkins.
True, the primary purpose of the rally is to work up enthusiasm to urge the team on to victory the following day. In the
past it has often been effectual; we trust it will continue to be.
But win or lose, the bonfire accomplishes a great deal in building
up college morale.

DR. EDMUNDS
Although news of his departure has been released for some
time, the fact that Dr. Edmunds has actually left the University
is difficult to realize. Dr. Edmunds' presence on the campus, and
in the efficiently organized Half Century office has been too deeply
impressed on the undergraduate memory to be easily forgotten.
The arrangement of the Half Century Celebration was a
tremendous task. The planning of the affair and the direction of
the great mass of detail were for the most part in the hands of
Dr. Edmunds. The success of the Anniversary was due in a
very large measure to his efforts.
We are sorry to see Dr. Edmunds leave Hopkins. It is true
that he is going into a larger field, one in which he is probably
more deeply interested; and it is equally certain that under the
direction of Dr. Ames the work will go on with as much success.
This, however, does not prevent our feeling that Hopkins has
lost a devoted worker and a distinct personality.

"YES and NO"
We all recognize, more or less, vividly the comparative
lethargy that follows examination; either by the faculty, an ardent
Goucherite or a fraternity. Now that rushing season is gone we
are minus a ready and efficacious self-excuser for our conscience,
that too well worn fallacy that after rushing season "to work
and sane living." In place of this talisman we substitute a term
that sounds well at home; "goes over" with some of the faculty
and has all the ear marks, but none of the drudgery, of absorbing knowledge. We call it "browsing" in the library. Perhaps,
in days gone it was possible in the Main Library to quite lose
oneself in a perusal of a favorite book, magazine or periodical
that catered to one's particular taste. And even now between
disturbed glances across the library at a glaring inch or so of
flesh between a jet dress and black-colored hose, we are conscious of an occasional interest in things pedagogical.
Our interest here is rather simple; so dubious in nature that
we hesitate to offer it. However, there is a little blue paper bound
pamphlet on the horseshoe table in the Main Library that is interesting from the point of view that novelty provokes interest.
As for example, if upon sitting down at a piano you were suddenly endowed with the power to produce sounds that were recognized as music, without previous knowledge, or acquisition of
skill. We picked up the little book to examine it, perfunctorily
as we do many foreign publications. Its title is "Academia pro
Interlingua." We leaved it over and were for the next few minutes engrossed in conveying to our mind concrete, definite images.
At first we were convinced that it was Latin—but voted that assumption out since we were reading it! Which is impossible.
On one of the pages we found the following which cleared the
fog considerably.
"Virtutes de Interlingua."
"Academia consilia pro Interlingua
Vocabulario internationale, Othographia latino, sine grammatica."
Orthographia latino redde interlingua intelligible sine studio
ad lectore que habe cognitione, et superficiale, de latino, id es ad
omne sacerdote, advocato, medico, professore, in toto mundus.
Suppressione de grammatica permitte ad lectore que ignora
latino, de lege et scribe in IL cum auxilio de solo vocabulario
latino."
We hesitate to say more of our reaction to the book, since
we have no desire to be identified with championing it. We wish
simply to wonder why the idea has not been exploited further.
Is it not novel that one may pick up a book produced by Polish
followers, published in Torino (wherever that is) and read it
without hesitation or study in America? What are the chief
objections to such a language; at least superficially, may we appeal to some member of the graduate department in Modern Languages to enlighten us. We are assured from many sources that
such a reply would be interesting reading.

MARSHALL NEILAN'S

To the Editor of YES AND No.
Dear Sir:
The Editor of YES AND NO was right in predicting that there
are supporters of a given policy, "however bad" it may be. We
do not believe, however, that the recent open week was altogether
bad; certainly it was not useless.
No matter how well a student knows a given fraternity before joining it, he is bound to find out later some things he was
not aware of. It is essential that the pledge know the character
and ideals of his would-be fraternity brothers, as well as their
social standing. We doubt if such a knowledge can be obtained
on the day of pledging.
The question of expense to the fraternity is mentioned by
the Editor; we are of the opinion that freshmen should pay their
own way at banquets and theatres. It is up to the fraternities
to so regulate their entertainments as not to impoverish themselves.
Lastly, we believe that ideals, no matter how hazy, are a
beneficial influence; they tend to place fraternity competition on
a higher, cleaner plane.
Sincerely,
RUSTICUS.
